text: How many more times? When I defend J Corbyn against press lies, I am NOT supporting (or attacking) his policies. Is logic really so hard?
author: RichardDawkins

text: For example, Corbyn's lament that bin Laden had not been brought to justice was twisted into "his death was a tragedy". I know the feeling.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Or satirising them, I hope accurately.https://twitter.com/RichardDawkins/status/644413675328159746 …
author: RichardDawkins

text: For example, most of my alleged "attacks" on various religious beliefs actually amount to no more than quoting them.https://twitter.com/RichardDawkins/status/644411449645862912 …
author: RichardDawkins

text: If a person says bad/silly things, expose them by quoting them. That should suffice to make your case. Inventing falsehoods is not the way.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Maybe many worries about Corbyn. But press lies make me suspicious. Much of what we've heard is false. Maybe the rest is. Crying wolf.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Common response when I point out an illogicality: "What d'you expect? It's Twitter." My reply: "Let's raise Twitter's game. Make it better."

text: To defend a man against press misrepresentation is not the same as supporting his policies. That's surely not a hard distinction to grasp?

author: RichardDawkins

text: @john_warring @normmacdonald It teaches you why you and all living things exist, why you have eyes, legs, brain. Yes, I consider you naive!
author: RichardDawkins

text: @normmacdonald From evolutionary pov it can be rational. Gene survival matters, not individual survival. Look up "suicide" in Selfish Gene.
author: RichardDawkins

text: @normmacdonald  This is a question for a psychologist, not an evolutionary biologist like me. If you'd lost all hope, family, career . . . ?
author: RichardDawkins

text: @normmacdonald     PS: realise it is counter-intuitive. 140 chars is not enough. That's why I wrote a whole book on it: The Selfish Gene.
author: RichardDawkins

text: @normmacdonald The "end" is simply to pass on the genes that all inherit from ancestors who succeeded in passing them on in the past.
author: RichardDawkins

text: @normmacdonald OK, I understand. All inherit the genes of an unbroken line of ancestors who worked to survive & reproduce (The Selfish Gene)
author: RichardDawkins

text: @normmacdonald Sorry I don't understand. What do you mean by "insist"?
author: RichardDawkins

author: RichardDawkins

text: Referendum system works well for the Swiss, does it? You think? I don't. They didn't give women the vote till 1970s!
author: RichardDawkins

text: If you seriously want to vote every day (I don't), we have the technology. But that wouldn't foster coherent, integrated economic etc policy
author: RichardDawkins

text: If y ou want a plebiscite on Europe, do you want a plebiscite on every other question? Do you want to vote every day or pay MPs to do it?
author: RichardDawkins

text: We have a parliamentary democracy. MPs are paid to do the homework we don't. Don't trust your MP? Then vote him/her out. Or stand yourself.
author: RichardDawkins

text: I'm not qualified to vote on leaving the EU. Nor are you unless you've made a full study of the issues. We are qualified to vote for an MP.
author: RichardDawkins

text: It's alarming how many people on Twitter haven't the faintest clue about the difference between plebiscite and parliamentary democracy.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Historians often use the historic present for vividness. But it can confuse. Dear Historians, the past tense is your tense. Please use it.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Always safe to use "might". "May" is wrong when the consequence can no longer happen. "But for the war I may never have been born" is wrong.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Although I applaud "I was like" as an enrichment, I couldn't use it myself. I'm the wrong age, it would sound ridiculous. Like "dude".
author: RichardDawkins

text: And the usurpation of the past tense by the present is an impoverishment. "I'm driving along" is taking over from "I was driving along."
author: RichardDawkins

text: But the loss of the may/might distinction is sad because it's meaningful & useful. And not difficult to grasp. I'm like "Save may/might".
author: RichardDawkins

text: We may flinch at "I was like . . .", but it is an enrichment because it's a brief way to say "Approximately but not exactly, I said . . ."
author: RichardDawkins

text: Language evolves. Memetically fascinating esp when a change ENRICHES (e.g. "I was like no way"). But LOSSES (e.g. may/might distinction) sad
author: RichardDawkins

text: New Statesman, you know my number. Why headline an accusatory question to me, when you could have phoned me and asked? Yes I believe her.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Obviously some drunk people remember well what happened. I was talking about a limited case where a witness admits she can't remember.
author: RichardDawkins

text: In my tweets I explicitly stated that I was considering the hypothetical case of a woman who testified that she COULDN'T REMEMBER.
author: RichardDawkins

text:
Yes, I believe you. Why would I not? Unlike the hypothetical case of my tweets, you have clear & convincing memories.
http://www.newstatesman.com/voices/2014/09/i-was-raped-when-i-was-drunk-i-was-14-do-you-believe-me-richard-dawkins …

text: Don't EVER rape anyone, drunk or sober. But also, don't accuse anyone of a crime if you can't remember what happened (& no other evidence).
author: RichardDawkins

text: Raping a drunk woman is appalling. So is jailing a man when the sole prosecution evidence is "I was too drunk to remember what happened."
author: RichardDawkins

text: .@mrgregariously Exactly. If you want to drive, don't get drunk. If you want to be in a position to testify & jail a man, don't get drunk.
author: RichardDawkins

text: .@em_dash01  Agreed. But also too drunk to provide enough testimony to jail someone. What if he claims he also was too drunk to consent?
author: RichardDawkins

text: .@faufcb  Yes. And there's also a presumption of innocence till proved guilty. Too drunk to REMEMBER is evidence to put someone in JAIL?
author: RichardDawkins

text: .@AssbanditXXX Yes of course. IF it's a fact. But jury doesn't know if it is. "Drunk in charge of your competence to testify": like car.
author: RichardDawkins

text: .@WellYesYouMay And do YOU not understand that a jury needs more convincing evidence than "I was too drunk to remember"?
author: RichardDawkins

text: .@DefuseSec  And too drunk for your evidence to stand up in a court of law? Rape is a serious crime. Need trustworthy evidence.
author: RichardDawkins

text: .@Jachra No, she MAY have been raped. If so, totally appalling. But it's her word against his and she admits she was too drunk to REMEMBER.

text: For moral decisions, it's often important to distinguish what now IS from what it potentially might BECOME. An acorn is not an oak tree.

text: Down Syndrome screening is not eugenic: DS has extremely low heritability. Screening offers a humane moral choice. Majority choose abortion.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Women have a right to early abortion. Choice is theirs. Down Syndrome is 1 of the commonest  & most moral reasons to exercise that right.
author: RichardDawkins

text: If I were a woman with a DS fetus I personally would abort. So do most women in fact. If you wouldn't, good luck to you, it's your decision,
author: RichardDawkins

text: Woman said she wouldn't know whether to abort. I told her what I would do & why. I OBVIOUSLY wouldn't TELL a woman what to do. Up to her.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Maryam Namazie & her ex-Muslim colleagues discuss Islamofascism. Includes brief interview with me. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=mr34ugMo5TA … Bread & Roses.
author: RichardDawkins

text: A woman whom I know & like said she'd be uncertain what to do if pregnant with Downs. I said what I'd do & why. Happens to be what most do.
author: RichardDawkins

text: I do not for one moment apologise for approaching moral philosophic questions in a logical way. There's a place for emotion & this isn't it.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Down syndrome screening is NOT eugenic. Almost always caused by non-hereditary chromosomal abnormality, heavily influenced by maternal age.
author: RichardDawkins

text: So, is anyone who doesn't follow Roman Catholic "morality" on abortion beyond the pale? Well I'm proud to be beyond that particular pale.
author: RichardDawkins

text: If you don't understand the point, look up "The Great Beethoven Fallacy" in The God Delusion.

text: Most countries accept a woman's right to abort. Elementary moral philosophy says this does NOT cast doubt on existing people's right to life
author: RichardDawkins

text: @dasendri Yes. Choice. People are entitled to make their choice. I stated the choice I would make. And that's the choice most often made.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Apparently I'm a horrid monster for recommending WHAT ACTUALLY HAPPENS to the great majority of Down Syndrome fetuses. They are aborted.
author: RichardDawkins

text: There's a profound moral difference between "This fetus should now be aborted" and "This person should have been aborted years ago."
author: RichardDawkins

text: In point of fact, a majority of Down Syndrome fetuses in Europe and USA are aborted. What I recommended is not outlandish but the norm.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Why do cave-dwellers lose their eyes? They're useless, but are they harmful? Costly to make? Or eroded by rain of uncorrected mutations?
author: RichardDawkins

text: Why do cells have the complete genome instead of just the part that's needed for their function? Liver cells have muscle-making genes etc.
author: RichardDawkins

text: "Why don't animals have wheels?" Good little (anonymous) lecture here:https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=sAGEOKAG0zw …
author: RichardDawkins

text: Why no biological wheels? Because no paved surfaces? Or because nerves & blood vessels would get twisted around axles?
author: RichardDawkins

text: My questions today about possible life forms are all questions that excite my sincere curiosity. Hope physicists might join in.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Why do nervous systems use slow, chemically mediated pulses of voltage change rather than fast electric currents along wires?
author: RichardDawkins

text: Why hasn't biological (as opposed to technological) evolution given rise to sense organs and transmitters in radio frequencies?
author: RichardDawkins

text: Stuart Kauffman's thought experiment: If evolution could be re-run 1000 times, would certain patterns predictably recur? Humanoids?
author: RichardDawkins

text: Does evolution rely upon digital genetics? Could there be an analogue genetics? What features of life have to be true all over the universe?
author: RichardDawkins

text: If our planet had been shrouded in perpetual fog, would eyes have evolved? In the sea, why not? But on land, what other sense organs?
author: RichardDawkins

text: @MUFC_MATT_95 @BRADT1 Of course it's subjective. The logic remains that our subjective ranking doesn't imply approval of the lesser evil.
author: RichardDawkins

text: @mazdachris82 That is the exact opposite of what I said, isn't it? All are serious. Some are more serious than others.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Yes, I can imagine circumstances where rape by a friend is worse than by a stranger. The logic remains. It doesn't imply approval of either.
author: RichardDawkins

text: "Talk of X/Y & we get the logic fine. But if a specific X/Y happens to wound our emotions, we become blinded to the very same logic." I see.
author: RichardDawkins

text: .@sublimecowgirl Of course, I readily see that. Just reverse my X/Y. Whichever you say is worse, it doesn't mean you endorse the other.
author: RichardDawkins

text: .@EVB_Now   Interesting, but my point stands. Simply reverse the X & Y in my syllogism. To say Y is worse than X is not an endorsement of X
author: RichardDawkins

text: "Mild date rape is bad. Violent date rape is worse." Is it really so hard to understand that that doesn't constitute endorsement of either?
author: RichardDawkins

text: .@mikester8821 Yes, it is so obvious it is painful. But they aren't debating, they are emoting.
author: RichardDawkins

text: What I have learned today is that there are people on Twitter who think in absolutist terms, to an extent I wouldn't have believed possible.
author: RichardDawkins

text: "Stealing £1 is bad. Stealing an old lady's life savings is worse." How DARE you rank them? Stealing is stealing. You're vile, appalling.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Whether X or Y is worse is a matter of opinion. But it is a matter of LOGIC that to express that opinion doesn't mean you approve of either.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Yes yes, you rank X and Y differently. Fine. Whichever you rank as worse, it is still illogical to interpret that as approval of the other.
author: RichardDawkins

text: If you prefer to think date rape is worse than knifepoint, simply reverse my syllogism. To say Y is worse than X is not an endorsement of Y.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Date rape is bad. Stranger rape at knifepoint is worse. If you think that's an endorsement of date rape, go away and learn how to think.
author: RichardDawkins

text: X is bad. Y is worse. If you think that's an endorsement of X, go away and don't come back until you've learned how to think logically.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Libertarians may call tax "theft". But don't assume the rest of us know what they mean if they treat them as synonyms without explanation.

text: Biologists use "kin" to mean genetic kin. Anthropologists often mean fictive kin. Neither field should impose its definition on the other.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Of course academic disciplines (like sociology) can redefine words for in-group discussions. But don't expect the rest us to follow suit.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Even bacteria are too complex to spontaneously generate (see Pasteur). They too evolved from simpler (spontaneously generated) precursors.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Complex things like mice or maggots had to evolve by slow, gradual steps from simple beginnings, ultimately spontaneously generated.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Pasteur didn't disprove spontaneous generation of mice or maggots. Always statistically obvious complexity couldn't spring up spontaneously.

text: Case in point: Obviously many philosophers “anticipated” Darwinism. But nobody before Darwin & Wallace saw its devastating significance.

text: On a Twitter roll, you write each new tweet in the context of its predecessors, forgetting that many readers aren’t seeing that context.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Yes indeed, it seems that Darwin needed the Beagle, not just an armchair. Er, that was kind of my POINT!
author: RichardDawkins

text: It's precisely BECAUSE philosophers did so many other brilliant things that I expressed amazement that they missed natural selection.
author: RichardDawkins

text: Goodness, I hit a nerve! I'm genuinely CURIOUS why Darwin's idea, simple enough to need only an armchair, had to wait for 19thC naturalists

text: Philosophers' historic failure to anticipate Darwin is a severe indictment of philosophy. Happy Darwin Day!

text: Darwin amazingly showed that complex, apparent design doesn't need a designer. Designers are unparsimoniously superfluous. Happy Darwin Day!

text: Darwin's idea – the most powerful idea ever? – is also spectacularly simple. Maybe that's why philosophers overlooked it. Happy Darwin Day.

text: Great philosophers like Hume could see the fallacy in Intelligent Design, but spectacularly failed to get the alternative. Happy Darwin Day!
